domains.name: Frameworks & Standards
domains.description: Industry-recognized cybersecurity and governance frameworks that provide structured approaches to managing information security, IT governance, and organizational risk.

topics.title: Introduction to GRC Frameworks
objectives: Explain what a GRC framework is and why organizations adopt them
Distinguish between frameworks, standards, regulations, and guidelines
Identify the major GRC frameworks and their primary use cases
topics.promptHints: Start with the big picture—why frameworks exist and the problems they solve. Use the analogy of building codes for cybersecurity. Compare voluntary frameworks (NIST CSF) vs. certifiable standards (ISO 27001) vs. regulatory mandates (PCI-DSS). Give real-world examples of companies choosing frameworks based on industry, geography, and maturity.

topics.title: NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) Overview
objectives: Describe the five core functions of NIST CSF (Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover)
Explain how Implementation Tiers indicate maturity
Create a basic Framework Profile for a hypothetical organization
topics.promptHints: Walk through each of the five functions with concrete examples—e.g., asset inventory for Identify, access controls for Protect. Discuss the NIST CSF 2.0 update and the addition of Govern. Use a small business scenario to show how someone would begin mapping their security posture to the framework. Emphasize that NIST CSF is voluntary but widely adopted.

topics.title: ISO 27001 Fundamentals
objectives: Explain the purpose and structure of ISO 27001 and ISO 27002
Describe the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) cycle in the context of an ISMS
List the key clauses and Annex A control categories
topics.promptHints: Explain ISO 27001 as an international certifiable standard for Information Security Management Systems. Contrast it with NIST CSF—ISO is prescriptive and auditable, NIST CSF is a flexible framework. Walk through the mandatory clauses (4-10) and explain Annex A controls at a high level. Use the example of a SaaS company pursuing ISO 27001 certification to win enterprise clients.

topics.title: SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria
objectives: Identify the five Trust Services Criteria (Security, Availability, Processing Integrity, Confidentiality, Privacy)
Distinguish between SOC 2 Type I and Type II reports
Explain why SOC 2 is important for service organizations
topics.promptHints: Frame SOC 2 as the 'gold standard' for SaaS and cloud service providers to demonstrate security to customers. Explain the difference between Type I (point-in-time) and Type II (over a period). Use real examples—a startup preparing for its first SOC 2 audit to close enterprise deals. Discuss common criteria mapping and how SOC 2 relates to other frameworks.

topics.title: Introduction to COBIT and CIS Controls
objectives: Describe COBIT's purpose as an IT governance framework
Explain the CIS Controls and their implementation groups
Compare when to use COBIT vs. CIS Controls vs. other frameworks
topics.promptHints: Position COBIT as the bridge between business goals and IT management—used heavily in enterprises and by IT auditors. Contrast with CIS Controls which are more tactical and prioritized for cybersecurity defense. Explain CIS Implementation Groups (IG1, IG2, IG3) and how a small org would start with IG1. Give a scenario where an organization uses COBIT for governance and CIS Controls for technical implementation.

topics.title: NIST 800-53 Security Controls Deep Dive
objectives: Navigate the NIST 800-53 control families and select appropriate controls
Apply control baselines (Low, Moderate, High) based on system categorization
Tailor controls using scoping and compensating control guidance
topics.promptHints: This is the workhorse of US federal cybersecurity. Explain the relationship between FIPS 199 (categorization), FIPS 200 (minimum requirements), and NIST 800-53 (control catalog). Walk through selecting controls for a moderate-impact system. Show how to tailor controls and document compensating controls. Use a government contractor scenario preparing for FISMA compliance.

topics.title: Framework Mapping and Crosswalks
objectives: Map controls between two or more frameworks (e.g., NIST CSF to ISO 27001)
Use crosswalk documents to streamline multi-framework compliance
Identify common controls that satisfy multiple framework requirements
topics.promptHints: Show how organizations dealing with multiple frameworks can avoid duplicate effort. Walk through a practical mapping exercise—e.g., map NIST CSF Identify function to ISO 27001 Annex A controls. Discuss tools like the NIST OLIR program and UCF. Use the scenario of a healthcare cloud provider that needs HIPAA, SOC 2, and ISO 27001 alignment.

topics.title: Implementing ISO 27001: Building an ISMS
objectives: Define the ISMS scope and boundaries for an organization
Conduct a gap analysis against ISO 27001 requirements
Develop a Statement of Applicability and risk treatment plan
topics.promptHints: Move from theory to practice—this is about actually building an ISMS. Walk through scoping decisions (which business units, locations, systems to include). Show how to perform a gap analysis by reviewing each clause and Annex A control. Discuss creating the Statement of Applicability and justifying excluded controls. Use a mid-size fintech company as the running example.

topics.title: SOC 2 Readiness and Control Implementation
objectives: Design and implement controls mapped to Trust Services Criteria
Prepare evidence packages for SOC 2 auditors
Identify and remediate gaps before a SOC 2 examination
topics.promptHints: Focus on the practical journey to SOC 2 compliance. Walk through a readiness assessment—identifying which TSC apply, documenting control descriptions, collecting evidence. Discuss common gaps (no formal change management, missing access reviews, inadequate logging). Use a B2B SaaS company preparing for their first SOC 2 Type II as the scenario.

topics.title: Maturity Models and Control Assessment
objectives: Apply capability maturity models (CMM/CMMI concepts) to security programs
Assess the maturity of controls using defined rating scales
Develop a roadmap to advance framework implementation maturity
topics.promptHints: Explain how maturity models help organizations measure where they are and plan where they need to go. Cover CMMI-style levels (Initial, Managed, Defined, Quantitatively Managed, Optimizing) applied to security. Walk through rating controls on a maturity scale and using results to prioritize improvements. Use the example of a company that passed its SOC 2 audit but wants to move from reactive to proactive security.

topics.title: Designing a Unified Control Framework
objectives: Architect a unified control framework that maps to multiple standards and regulations
Rationalize overlapping controls to reduce redundancy and audit fatigue
Establish a governance model for maintaining the unified framework over time
topics.promptHints: This is a strategic, senior-level topic. Discuss how large enterprises consolidate dozens of frameworks into a single internal control framework. Cover the design process—selecting a base framework, mapping others to it, identifying unique controls. Discuss governance for keeping it current as frameworks update. Use a global financial services firm as the example, dealing with SOX, PCI-DSS, GDPR, ISO 27001, and NIST simultaneously.

topics.title: Framework Selection and Program Strategy
objectives: Evaluate and recommend frameworks based on organizational context, industry, and regulatory requirements
Build a business case for framework adoption including cost-benefit analysis
Design a phased implementation strategy with milestones and success metrics
topics.promptHints: Position this as a CISO-level decision. Walk through how to evaluate which frameworks to adopt—considering industry (healthcare vs. finance vs. tech), geography (US vs. EU vs. global), customer requirements, and regulatory mandates. Show how to build a compelling business case with ROI analysis. Use the scenario of a newly hired CISO at a growing company that has no formal security framework.

topics.title: Automation and GRC Tooling for Framework Management
objectives: Evaluate GRC platforms for framework management and compliance automation
Design automated evidence collection and control monitoring workflows
Implement continuous compliance monitoring using APIs and integrations
topics.promptHints: Cover the technology landscape—tools like ServiceNow GRC, Drata, Vanta, Archer, OneTrust, and how they automate framework compliance. Discuss automated evidence collection (pulling configs from AWS, Azure, GCP), continuous control monitoring, and reducing manual audit prep. Walk through designing an automation workflow for a SOC 2 program. Discuss build vs. buy decisions.

topics.title: Emerging Frameworks and Regulatory Trends
objectives: Analyze emerging cybersecurity frameworks and their implications (e.g., NIST AI RMF, SEC cyber rules)
Assess the impact of evolving regulations on existing framework implementations
Develop strategies for adapting GRC programs to regulatory change
topics.promptHints: Look at what's coming next in the frameworks world. Cover NIST AI RMF for AI governance, SEC cybersecurity disclosure rules, EU's DORA for financial services, NIS2 directive, and the push toward software supply chain security (NIST SSDF). Discuss how organizations should do regulatory horizon scanning and maintain adaptable GRC programs. Frame this as strategic planning for the next 3-5 years.

topics.title: Communicating Framework Value to Executive Leadership
objectives: Translate framework compliance status into executive-level dashboards and metrics
Present framework adoption ROI to board members and C-suite stakeholders
Align framework reporting with business objectives and risk appetite
topics.promptHints: Bridge the gap between technical framework compliance and business value. Show how to build executive dashboards that translate control compliance percentages into business risk language. Discuss key metrics: coverage ratios, time-to-compliance, cost per control, audit findings trends. Walk through a board presentation scenario where you're justifying continued investment in the GRC program.

domains.name: Risk Management
domains.description: Systematic identification, analysis, evaluation, and treatment of risks to organizational objectives, including quantitative and qualitative methodologies, enterprise risk management, and risk-informed decision making.

topics.title: Introduction to Risk Management Concepts
objectives: Define risk, threat, vulnerability, likelihood, and impact in a security context
Explain the risk management lifecycle and its key phases
Describe common risk management frameworks (ISO 31000, NIST RMF, COSO ERM)
topics.promptHints: Build intuition around risk using everyday analogies before diving into security-specific definitions. Explain the risk equation (Risk = Threat × Vulnerability × Impact). Cover the basic lifecycle: identify, analyze, evaluate, treat, monitor. Introduce the major risk frameworks at a high level. Use examples like a retail company assessing the risk of a data breach.

topics.title: Risk Identification Techniques
objectives: Apply brainstorming, checklists, and interview techniques to identify risks
Categorize risks by type (strategic, operational, financial, compliance, cyber)
Document identified risks using a structured risk register format
topics.promptHints: Focus on practical techniques for finding risks. Walk through a brainstorming session, show how to use checklists from frameworks, and demonstrate interview techniques for gathering risk information from stakeholders. Show a sample risk register and explain each field. Use the scenario of a company launching a new cloud-based product and identifying associated risks.

topics.title: Qualitative Risk Analysis
objectives: Construct and use a risk matrix (likelihood × impact) to rate risks
Apply consistent rating scales for likelihood and impact
Prioritize risks based on qualitative analysis results
topics.promptHints: This is the most common risk analysis method in practice. Walk through building a 5×5 risk matrix with clear definitions for each level. Show how to rate risks consistently across the organization. Discuss common pitfalls—subjective bias, anchoring, inconsistent scales. Use examples of rating risks like ransomware attack, insider threat, and regulatory fine.

topics.title: Risk Treatment Options
objectives: Explain the four risk treatment strategies: mitigate, accept, transfer, avoid
Select appropriate risk treatments based on risk analysis results
Document risk treatment decisions and develop action plans
topics.promptHints: Use clear examples for each treatment option—mitigate (implement MFA to reduce credential theft risk), transfer (buy cyber insurance), avoid (don't store credit card data), accept (acknowledge low-impact risk with documented rationale). Discuss when each option is appropriate and how to determine residual risk after treatment. Show how to create a risk treatment plan with owners, deadlines, and success criteria.

topics.title: Risk Appetite, Tolerance, and Thresholds
objectives: Distinguish between risk appetite, risk tolerance, and risk capacity
Explain how risk appetite statements guide decision-making
Identify when a risk exceeds organizational tolerance thresholds
topics.promptHints: Use the personal finance analogy—appetite is how much risk you want to take, tolerance is how much you can handle, capacity is the maximum you can survive. Show real examples of risk appetite statements from different industries. Discuss how these concepts drive actual decisions—what happens when a risk exceeds tolerance? Who decides? Walk through a scenario where a CISO presents a risk that exceeds the organization's stated appetite.

topics.title: Quantitative Risk Analysis Methods
objectives: Calculate Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE) using SLE and ARO
Apply the FAIR (Factor Analysis of Information Risk) model to decompose risk
Compare quantitative and qualitative approaches and when to use each
topics.promptHints: Walk through the classic ALE calculation step by step with real numbers—e.g., a data breach with an SLE of $500K and ARO of 0.2 gives an ALE of $100K. Then introduce FAIR as a more sophisticated approach that decomposes risk into threat event frequency and loss magnitude. Show how Monte Carlo simulation provides a range of outcomes. Discuss limitations of both approaches and when to use quantitative vs. qualitative.

topics.title: Risk Assessment Methodologies
objectives: Conduct a structured risk assessment following NIST 800-30 methodology
Perform threat modeling using STRIDE or PASTA frameworks
Document and present risk assessment findings to stakeholders
topics.promptHints: Walk through a complete risk assessment from scoping to reporting. Use NIST 800-30 as the primary methodology—identify threat sources, threat events, vulnerabilities, likelihood, and impact. Show how STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege) helps identify threats systematically. Include a sample risk assessment report outline. Use a web application risk assessment as the working example.

topics.title: Risk Registers and Risk Reporting
objectives: Design and maintain a comprehensive risk register with all required fields
Create risk reports and dashboards for different audiences (operational, executive, board)
Track risk trends and key risk indicators (KRIs) over time
topics.promptHints: Go deep on the risk register as a living document. Cover all essential fields: risk ID, description, category, owner, inherent rating, controls, residual rating, treatment plan, status, last review date. Show how to build different views for different audiences. Discuss KRIs and how to set thresholds that trigger action. Use the example of a quarterly risk review process at a mid-size financial services firm.

topics.title: Control Effectiveness and Risk Reduction
objectives: Evaluate the design and operating effectiveness of security controls
Measure how controls reduce inherent risk to residual risk levels
Identify control gaps and develop remediation priorities
topics.promptHints: Bridge risk management and control frameworks. Show how to assess whether a control is well-designed (design effectiveness) and whether it's actually working (operating effectiveness). Walk through calculating residual risk after applying controls. Discuss the concept of defense in depth and how multiple controls reduce risk. Use the example of evaluating access control effectiveness across an organization.

topics.title: IT and Cyber Risk Scenarios
objectives: Develop realistic cyber risk scenarios using threat intelligence
Estimate financial impact of cyber incidents using industry data
Use scenario analysis to stress-test risk management decisions
topics.promptHints: Build practical cyber risk scenarios using real-world data. Reference the Verizon DBIR, IBM Cost of a Data Breach report, and Ponemon studies for realistic numbers. Walk through creating scenarios like 'ransomware attack on critical systems' or 'insider data exfiltration' with estimated frequency and financial impact. Show how scenario analysis informs investment decisions—should we spend $200K on a new tool that reduces a $2M risk by 60%?

topics.title: Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) Integration
objectives: Design an ERM program that integrates cyber risk with operational, financial, and strategic risk
Implement COSO ERM or ISO 31000 across the enterprise
Establish risk governance structures including risk committees and escalation paths
topics.promptHints: This is the strategic, enterprise-wide view. Show how cyber/IT risk fits into the broader ERM landscape alongside financial, operational, strategic, and reputational risk. Walk through implementing COSO ERM—its five components and 20 principles. Discuss risk governance: who sits on the risk committee, how often they meet, escalation paths, and how risk is integrated into strategic planning. Use a large healthcare organization as the example.

topics.title: Advanced Risk Quantification with FAIR
objectives: Build a complete FAIR risk analysis for a complex scenario with multiple threat communities
Use Monte Carlo simulation tools to generate loss exceedance curves
Present risk quantification results to support capital allocation decisions
topics.promptHints: Go deep on FAIR as a quantitative risk model. Walk through the complete FAIR ontology—Loss Event Frequency (TEF × Vulnerability) and Loss Magnitude (Primary Loss + Secondary Loss). Show how to estimate inputs using calibrated expert judgment. Demonstrate Monte Carlo simulation results and how to read a loss exceedance curve. Use this to answer the question: 'What is the probable range of losses from a cloud data breach over the next 12 months?'

topics.title: Risk-Informed Decision Making
objectives: Apply risk analysis results to prioritize security investments and resource allocation
Use decision trees and cost-benefit analysis for risk treatment selection
Integrate risk information into strategic planning and budgeting processes
topics.promptHints: This is about using risk data to make better business decisions. Show how to build a cost-benefit analysis for security investments—compare ALE reduction to control implementation and maintenance costs. Walk through a decision tree for choosing between risk treatment options. Discuss how to present risk-based budget requests to CFOs and boards. Use the example of justifying a $1M investment in a Zero Trust architecture.

topics.title: Emerging and Systemic Risk
objectives: Identify and assess emerging risks (AI, quantum computing, geopolitical, climate)
Analyze systemic and concentration risks across the organization and its ecosystem
Develop early warning indicators and horizon scanning processes
topics.promptHints: Look beyond traditional risks to emerging threats. Discuss AI-enabled attacks, quantum computing threats to cryptography, supply chain concentration risk (everyone on AWS), geopolitical risks affecting data sovereignty, and climate-related risks to infrastructure. Show how to build a horizon scanning process and develop early warning indicators. Use scenarios like 'What if a major cloud provider goes down for a week?' or 'How does quantum computing affect our encryption timeline?'

topics.title: Building a Risk-Aware Culture
objectives: Design programs that embed risk awareness into organizational culture and decision-making
Develop risk champion networks and risk communication strategies
Measure and improve risk culture maturity across the organization
topics.promptHints: Risk management fails without the right culture. Discuss how to move beyond checkbox compliance to genuine risk awareness. Cover strategies: risk champion networks in business units, risk-based decision frameworks for project managers, gamified risk training, and executive 'tone at the top.' Show how to measure risk culture maturity using surveys and behavioral indicators. Use the example of a company that had a major breach because risks were identified but not escalated due to cultural barriers.

domains.name: Compliance & Regulatory
domains.description: Understanding and meeting legal, regulatory, and contractual obligations across jurisdictions and industries, including data privacy, financial regulations, and sector-specific requirements.

topics.title: Introduction to Regulatory Compliance
objectives: Explain the difference between regulatory compliance, contractual compliance, and voluntary standards
Identify the consequences of non-compliance (fines, legal action, reputational damage)
Describe the role of regulators and enforcement agencies
topics.promptHints: Start with why compliance matters—use real examples of fines and enforcement actions (Equifax, British Airways GDPR fine, HIPAA settlements). Explain the hierarchy: laws → regulations → standards → guidance. Discuss different regulators (FTC, HHS OCR, ICO, SEC) and their enforcement powers. Use the scenario of a company expanding into a new market and discovering new compliance obligations.

topics.title: GDPR Fundamentals
objectives: Identify the key principles and rights established by GDPR
Determine when GDPR applies to an organization (territorial scope)
Explain the roles of data controller, data processor, and Data Protection Officer
topics.promptHints: Cover the seven GDPR principles (lawfulness, purpose limitation, data minimization, accuracy, storage limitation, integrity/confidentiality, accountability). Explain the six lawful bases for processing. Discuss extraterritorial scope—how GDPR applies to US companies handling EU data. Walk through data subject rights (access, rectification, erasure, portability). Use the example of a US e-commerce company that starts selling to European customers.

topics.title: HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules
objectives: Distinguish between HIPAA Privacy Rule, Security Rule, and Breach Notification Rule
Identify covered entities and business associates under HIPAA
List the administrative, physical, and technical safeguards required
topics.promptHints: Focus on practical HIPAA understanding for GRC professionals. Explain what PHI is with clear examples. Walk through the Privacy Rule (use and disclosure rules, minimum necessary standard) and Security Rule (administrative, physical, technical safeguards). Discuss Business Associate Agreements and the chain of liability. Use the scenario of a healthtech startup building an app that handles patient data.

topics.title: PCI-DSS Requirements Overview
objectives: List the 12 PCI-DSS requirements and their purpose
Determine PCI-DSS merchant and service provider levels
Explain the difference between SAQ, ROC, and AOC
topics.promptHints: Frame PCI-DSS as the payment card industry's mandatory security standard. Walk through the 12 requirements grouped by the six goals. Explain how to determine merchant level (1-4 based on transaction volume) and the corresponding validation requirements. Discuss the role of QSAs, SAQs, and the AOC. Use the example of an online retailer determining their PCI scope and validation requirements.

topics.title: US Privacy Laws: CCPA, State Privacy, and Federal Landscape
objectives: Explain CCPA/CPRA consumer rights and business obligations
Compare major US state privacy laws and their key differences
Describe the current US federal privacy landscape and pending legislation
topics.promptHints: Cover the evolving US privacy patchwork. Start with CCPA/CPRA—rights to know, delete, opt-out, and correct. Discuss thresholds for applicability. Compare with other state laws (Virginia VCDPA, Colorado CPA, Connecticut CTDPA, etc.) highlighting key differences. Touch on the push for federal privacy legislation. Use the scenario of a company operating in all 50 states trying to build a unified privacy compliance program.

topics.title: Building a Compliance Program
objectives: Design a compliance program structure with roles, responsibilities, and governance
Develop compliance policies, procedures, and training programs
Implement compliance monitoring, testing, and reporting mechanisms
topics.promptHints: Walk through building a compliance program from scratch. Cover the seven elements of an effective compliance program (DOJ guidance). Discuss organizational structure—where the compliance function sits, reporting lines, independence. Show how to develop a compliance obligations register, create policies mapped to requirements, and implement monitoring. Use a healthcare company building its HIPAA compliance program as the running example.

topics.title: Data Privacy Program Management
objectives: Conduct data mapping and create records of processing activities (ROPA)
Implement Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) for high-risk processing
Manage data subject requests and consent at scale
topics.promptHints: Focus on the operational aspects of running a privacy program. Walk through data mapping—discovering what personal data exists, where it lives, who has access, and how it flows. Show how to create a ROPA and when DPIAs are required. Discuss implementing DSR workflows (authentication, response timelines, exceptions). Cover consent management platforms and preference centers. Use a SaaS company handling data across multiple jurisdictions.

topics.title: SOX IT Compliance
objectives: Explain the IT General Controls (ITGCs) relevant to SOX compliance
Identify and test key automated and manual controls over financial reporting
Support SOX audit readiness with proper documentation and evidence
topics.promptHints: Cover SOX from the IT perspective—how IT controls support financial reporting integrity. Walk through the four ITGC categories: access to programs and data, program changes, computer operations, and program development. Show how to identify key controls, test them, and document results. Discuss the severity of findings (deficiency vs. significant deficiency vs. material weakness). Use a publicly traded company preparing for its annual SOX audit.

topics.title: FedRAMP and Government Compliance
objectives: Describe the FedRAMP authorization process and its three paths
Map FedRAMP requirements to NIST 800-53 control baselines
Prepare a System Security Plan (SSP) and supporting documentation
topics.promptHints: Cover FedRAMP as the gateway for cloud service providers selling to the federal government. Explain the three authorization paths (JAB, Agency, CSP-initiated). Walk through the documentation requirements—SSP, SAR, POA&M. Discuss the relationship to NIST 800-53 and the additional FedRAMP-specific requirements. Use the scenario of a cloud company pursuing FedRAMP Moderate authorization to sell to federal agencies.

topics.title: Cross-Border Data Transfers and International Compliance
objectives: Navigate GDPR cross-border data transfer mechanisms (SCCs, adequacy decisions, BCRs)
Implement data localization requirements for different jurisdictions
Manage compliance across multiple regulatory regimes simultaneously
topics.promptHints: Address the complexity of international data flows. Cover GDPR transfer mechanisms post-Schrems II—SCCs (2021 version), adequacy decisions, BCRs, and derogations. Discuss data localization laws in countries like Russia, China, India, and Brazil. Show how to conduct a transfer impact assessment. Use the example of a multinational company with offices in the US, EU, and Asia-Pacific managing data flows between regions.

topics.title: Regulatory Strategy and Engagement
objectives: Develop a proactive regulatory engagement strategy including comment letters and industry participation
Anticipate regulatory changes and position the organization for compliance
Navigate regulatory examinations and enforcement actions
topics.promptHints: Move from reactive compliance to strategic regulatory engagement. Discuss how to monitor proposed regulations, participate in comment periods, and engage with regulators proactively. Cover preparing for and managing regulatory examinations (on-site visits, document requests, interviews). Walk through responding to enforcement actions—remediation plans, consent decrees, settlement negotiations. Use the scenario of a financial services firm navigating multiple concurrent regulatory examinations.

topics.title: AI Governance and Emerging Technology Compliance
objectives: Apply the EU AI Act classification system and compliance requirements
Implement AI governance frameworks including model risk management and bias monitoring
Navigate emerging regulations around AI, IoT, and blockchain
topics.promptHints: Cover the rapidly evolving regulatory landscape for AI and emerging technologies. Walk through the EU AI Act risk classification (unacceptable, high-risk, limited, minimal) and compliance obligations for each tier. Discuss US AI governance (NIST AI RMF, executive orders, sector-specific guidance). Show how to implement AI governance: model inventories, bias testing, explainability requirements, and human oversight. Use the example of a company deploying AI for credit decisions or hiring.

topics.title: Multi-Jurisdictional Compliance Architecture
objectives: Design a scalable compliance architecture for global operations
Harmonize conflicting regulatory requirements across jurisdictions
Build compliance centers of excellence and regional compliance structures
topics.promptHints: Address the challenge of managing compliance globally at scale. Discuss how to design a compliance operating model—centralized vs. federated vs. hybrid. Show how to handle conflicting requirements (e.g., GDPR right to erasure vs. financial record retention requirements). Cover building compliance centers of excellence with specialized expertise. Use a global technology company operating in 40+ countries as the example.

topics.title: Compliance Metrics, Reporting, and Board Communication
objectives: Design compliance KPIs and metrics that demonstrate program effectiveness
Build board-level compliance reports and regulatory risk dashboards
Use compliance analytics to identify trends and predict regulatory issues
topics.promptHints: Show how to measure and communicate compliance program effectiveness. Cover leading and lagging indicators—training completion rates, policy exception trends, audit finding closure rates, regulatory inquiry response times. Discuss board reporting requirements and how to present compliance status concisely. Introduce compliance analytics—using data to identify patterns and predict issues before they become findings. Walk through building a quarterly compliance report for the board.

topics.title: Industry-Specific Regulatory Deep Dive
objectives: Analyze sector-specific regulatory frameworks for financial services, healthcare, or critical infrastructure
Design compliance programs that address industry-specific nuances and expectations
Navigate industry regulators and self-regulatory organizations
topics.promptHints: Deep dive into how compliance differs by industry. Cover financial services (GLBA, FFIEC, OCC guidance, SEC/FINRA), healthcare (HIPAA, HITECH, FDA, state health laws), energy/utilities (NERC CIP), and defense/government (CMMC, ITAR, EAR). Discuss self-regulatory organizations and how they layer on top of government regulation. Show how to design an industry-specific compliance program. Use the scenario of a company pivoting from tech to a regulated industry.

domains.name: Audit & Assurance
domains.description: Planning, executing, and reporting on audits to provide independent assurance over the effectiveness of controls, compliance with policies, and accuracy of organizational claims.

topics.title: Introduction to IT Audit and Assurance
objectives: Explain the purpose and types of audits (internal, external, regulatory)
Describe the role and responsibilities of IT auditors
Identify key IT audit standards and guidelines (ISACA, IIA)
topics.promptHints: Build foundational understanding of what auditors do and why. Explain the three lines of defense model and where audit sits. Distinguish internal audit (organizational function) from external audit (independent firm) from regulatory examination. Cover the key professional standards—ISACA's ITAF, IIA's IPPF. Discuss the audit charter and auditor independence. Use the example of a new hire joining an internal audit team at a financial services company.

topics.title: The Audit Lifecycle
objectives: Describe the phases of an audit: planning, fieldwork, reporting, follow-up
Explain how audit scope and objectives are determined
Create a basic audit plan with timeline and resource requirements
topics.promptHints: Walk through a complete audit lifecycle from start to finish. Cover planning (understanding the area, risk assessment, scoping), fieldwork (testing, evidence collection, interviews), reporting (findings, recommendations, management response), and follow-up (tracking remediation). Show a sample audit plan with scope statement, objectives, timeline, and team assignments. Use the example of planning an audit of access management controls.

topics.title: Evidence Gathering and Documentation
objectives: Identify the types of audit evidence and their relative reliability
Apply evidence gathering techniques: inquiry, observation, inspection, re-performance
Document audit work in workpapers that support conclusions
topics.promptHints: Evidence is the foundation of audit conclusions. Explain the hierarchy of evidence reliability—external vs. internal, documentary vs. oral. Walk through each gathering technique with examples: inquiry (interviewing the sys admin), observation (watching a backup process), inspection (reviewing access reports), re-performance (testing a control yourself). Show what good workpapers look like and why documentation standards matter. Use a practical example of gathering evidence for a change management audit.

topics.title: Understanding Controls and Control Testing
objectives: Classify controls as preventive, detective, or corrective
Distinguish between design effectiveness and operating effectiveness testing
Select appropriate sample sizes and testing methods
topics.promptHints: Connect the dots between controls and audit testing. Explain control types with clear examples—preventive (MFA prevents unauthorized access), detective (log monitoring detects anomalies), corrective (incident response corrects breaches). Walk through testing design effectiveness (does the control address the risk?) vs. operating effectiveness (has it been working consistently?). Cover sampling basics—how many items to test and why. Use the example of testing the user access provisioning process.

topics.title: Audit Findings and Reporting
objectives: Write clear audit findings using the condition-criteria-cause-effect format
Rate finding severity and develop practical recommendations
Draft an audit report that communicates results effectively
topics.promptHints: Findings are the deliverable—teach how to write them well. Walk through the finding format: Condition (what you found), Criteria (what should have been), Cause (why the gap exists), Effect (why it matters). Show examples of well-written vs. poorly-written findings. Discuss rating severity (critical, high, medium, low). Cover report structure: executive summary, scope, methodology, findings, recommendations. Use examples of common IT audit findings like access review gaps or incomplete change management.

topics.title: SOC Report Auditing
objectives: Explain the differences between SOC 1, SOC 2, and SOC 3 reports
Evaluate a SOC 2 report as a user entity (reading and assessing the report)
Plan and execute a SOC 2 Type II examination as a service organization
topics.promptHints: Deep dive into SOC reports—the backbone of vendor assurance. Explain when to use SOC 1 (financial reporting controls, SSAE 18) vs. SOC 2 (TSC-based) vs. SOC 3 (public report). Show how to read a SOC 2 report critically—management assertion, system description, tests of controls, results. Walk through planning a SOC 2 Type II—scoping, control identification, evidence preparation, auditor coordination. Discuss carve-out vs. inclusive method for subservice organizations.

topics.title: Risk-Based Audit Planning
objectives: Develop a risk-based annual audit plan aligned with organizational risk profile
Prioritize audit universe items using risk scoring methodologies
Allocate audit resources based on risk priorities and stakeholder needs
topics.promptHints: Show how to build a risk-based audit plan rather than a rotation-based one. Walk through creating the audit universe—listing all auditable entities (business units, processes, systems, projects). Develop a risk scoring model using factors like inherent risk, control maturity, time since last audit, regulatory sensitivity, and recent changes. Show how to prioritize and allocate limited audit resources. Use a technology company with 50+ auditable areas and resources for 20 audits per year.

topics.title: IT General Controls (ITGC) Auditing
objectives: Audit the four ITGC domains: access management, change management, computer operations, and program development
Design test procedures for common ITGCs with appropriate sample sizes
Identify control deficiencies and their impact on financial reporting or security
topics.promptHints: This is bread-and-butter IT audit work. Walk through each ITGC domain with specific test procedures. Access management: test user provisioning, termination, access reviews, privileged access. Change management: test change approval workflows, separation of duties, emergency changes. Computer operations: test job scheduling, backup and recovery, incident management. Program development: test SDLC controls, testing requirements, deployment procedures. Include sample sizes and what constitutes a failure. Use real-world examples of common ITGC findings.

topics.title: Audit Data Analytics and CAATs
objectives: Apply Computer-Assisted Audit Techniques (CAATs) to improve audit efficiency
Use data analytics to identify anomalies, trends, and high-risk populations
Design data-driven audit tests that provide greater coverage than sampling
topics.promptHints: Show how data analytics transforms audit from sample-based to full-population testing. Cover common CAATs: data extraction (SQL, ACL/IDEA), analysis (duplicate detection, gap analysis, Benford's Law), and visualization. Walk through practical examples—analyzing the full population of access changes to find unauthorized modifications, or analyzing all journal entries to find unusual patterns. Discuss tools available and skills needed. Use the example of using analytics to audit expense reports or access logs.

topics.title: Managing the Audit Relationship
objectives: Build effective working relationships with auditees and stakeholders
Manage audit conflicts and challenging audit situations diplomatically
Track and validate remediation of audit findings
topics.promptHints: The soft skills of auditing are crucial. Discuss how to build trust with auditees—being collaborative vs. adversarial. Cover managing difficult situations: auditees who are unresponsive, management who disagrees with findings, executives who pressure for lower severity ratings. Walk through the remediation lifecycle—tracking findings, validating remediation evidence, re-testing, and closing findings. Discuss addressing audit fatigue when the organization is over-audited. Use real scenarios of audit conflicts and their resolution.

topics.title: Continuous Auditing and Monitoring
objectives: Design a continuous auditing program that provides real-time assurance
Implement automated control monitoring dashboards and alerting
Transition from periodic to continuous audit methodologies
topics.promptHints: This is the future of audit. Explain the difference between continuous auditing (audit function) and continuous monitoring (management function). Show how to identify controls suitable for continuous monitoring—high-frequency, data-rich, automatable. Walk through building automated tests (e.g., daily check for users without recent access reviews, automated change management compliance checks). Discuss the technology stack needed and how to present continuous audit results. Use the example of building a continuous auditing program for ITGCs.

topics.title: Cloud and Emerging Technology Auditing
objectives: Audit cloud environments (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) and shared responsibility models
Assess controls for emerging technologies: AI/ML, containers, serverless, IoT
Adapt traditional audit procedures for DevOps and agile environments
topics.promptHints: Cover how audit must evolve for modern technology. Start with cloud auditing—understanding the shared responsibility model (what the CSP controls vs. what the customer controls) and auditing each layer. Then cover auditing in DevOps environments—CI/CD pipelines, infrastructure as code, ephemeral infrastructure. Discuss emerging technology audit challenges: how do you audit an AI model? How do you test container security? Use the scenario of auditing a company that has moved 80% of its infrastructure to AWS.

topics.title: Building and Leading an Audit Function
objectives: Establish an internal audit function with appropriate charter, structure, and staffing
Develop audit team competencies and professional development programs
Implement quality assurance and improvement programs (QAIP)
topics.promptHints: Cover the leadership aspects of running an audit function. Discuss establishing the audit charter, organizational positioning (reporting to audit committee), and staffing models (in-house, co-sourced, outsourced). Walk through building team competencies—certifications (CISA, CIA, CISSP), training programs, career paths. Cover QAIP requirements per IIA standards—internal assessments and external quality reviews. Use the scenario of a company that has grown large enough to need its own internal audit function.

topics.title: Integrated Assurance and Combined Assurance Models
objectives: Design an integrated assurance model that coordinates across audit, risk, and compliance
Reduce duplication of effort among first, second, and third lines of defense
Present a unified assurance view to the audit committee and board
topics.promptHints: Address the problem of assurance silos—multiple teams testing the same controls independently. Walk through the IIA's Three Lines Model and how to coordinate assurance activities. Show how to create an assurance map that identifies who provides assurance over what, and where gaps or overlaps exist. Discuss establishing assurance forums, sharing workpapers and results, and presenting a unified view. Use a large enterprise scenario where internal audit, external audit, compliance, and risk management are all testing similar controls.

topics.title: Audit Committee and Board Engagement
objectives: Prepare and present audit results to audit committees effectively
Navigate audit committee dynamics and expectations
Align audit priorities with organizational strategy and board concerns
topics.promptHints: This is the pinnacle of audit leadership—engaging with the board and audit committee. Cover what audit committees expect: overall opinion on control environment, significant findings, emerging risks, and audit plan updates. Show how to prepare audit committee presentations—concise, risk-focused, with clear conclusions and actionable recommendations. Discuss navigating difficult conversations: reporting significant deficiencies, disagreements with management, and requesting additional resources. Use real examples of audit committee questions and how to handle them.

domains.name: Policy & Governance
domains.description: Creating, implementing, and maintaining organizational policies, governance structures, and management systems that direct and oversee information security and compliance programs.

topics.title: Introduction to Information Security Governance
objectives: Define governance and distinguish it from management in the security context
Identify key governance components: structures, processes, and relational mechanisms
Explain how governance enables organizational accountability for security
topics.promptHints: Clarify the distinction between governance (directing and controlling) and management (planning and executing). Use corporate governance analogies—board vs. CEO. Explain how security governance ensures that security investments align with business objectives and risks are managed to acceptable levels. Cover the three mechanisms: structures (committees, roles), processes (policies, reviews), and relational (culture, communication). Use the example of a fast-growing startup realizing they need formal governance.

topics.title: Policy Hierarchy: Policies, Standards, Procedures, and Guidelines
objectives: Distinguish between policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines
Explain the purpose and audience for each document type
Identify the essential information security policies every organization needs
topics.promptHints: Use a clear pyramid or hierarchy model. Policies are high-level management intent ('what'), standards define specific requirements ('how much'), procedures are step-by-step instructions ('how'), and guidelines are recommendations ('you should'). Give concrete examples: Acceptable Use Policy → Password Standard (min 12 characters, complexity) → Password Change Procedure → Password Selection Guideline. List the essential policies: acceptable use, access control, data classification, incident response, BYOD, etc.

topics.title: Writing Effective Security Policies
objectives: Draft clear, enforceable security policies using standard formats
Include all necessary policy components (purpose, scope, roles, statements, enforcement)
Avoid common policy writing mistakes (ambiguity, over-prescription, staleness)
topics.promptHints: Teach the craft of policy writing. Cover the essential sections: purpose, scope, definitions, policy statements, roles and responsibilities, enforcement, exceptions, and revision history. Show before-and-after examples of poor vs. good policy language—e.g., 'Users should use strong passwords' (bad) vs. 'All users must authenticate using passwords that meet the requirements defined in the Password Standard' (good). Discuss tone, readability, and avoiding jargon that non-technical staff won't understand.

topics.title: Roles and Responsibilities in Security
objectives: Define common security roles: CISO, security analysts, security champions, data owners
Explain the concept of ownership and how it applies to assets, risks, and data
Create a RACI matrix for security activities
topics.promptHints: Clarify who is responsible for what in security. Walk through the key roles and their responsibilities—CISO (strategy and oversight), security team (implementation and monitoring), data owners (classification and access decisions), data custodians (technical safeguards), end users (following policy). Explain the RACI matrix (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed) and build one for a common process like incident response or access provisioning. Discuss the challenge of assigning ownership in matrixed organizations.

topics.title: Data Classification and Handling
objectives: Design a data classification scheme appropriate for the organization
Define handling requirements for each classification level
Implement data labeling and user awareness for classification
topics.promptHints: Data classification is foundational to many other security controls. Walk through designing a classification scheme—typically 3-4 levels (Public, Internal, Confidential, Restricted/Top Secret). For each level, define handling requirements: storage (encryption at rest?), transmission (encryption in transit?), access (who can see it?), disposal (how to destroy it?), and labeling (how to mark it?). Discuss challenges: getting business units to actually classify data, handling mixed-classification databases, and automated classification tools.

topics.title: Governance Structures and Committees
objectives: Design security governance committee structures with clear charters and membership
Establish a security steering committee with appropriate executive participation
Create effective meeting cadences, agendas, and decision-making processes
topics.promptHints: Cover how to set up governance bodies that actually work. Discuss the typical committee structure: security steering committee (executive-level, quarterly), security working group (management-level, monthly), and tactical teams (operational, weekly/daily). Walk through writing a committee charter—purpose, scope, membership, decision authority, meeting frequency. Show sample agendas and how to drive decisions rather than just share information. Discuss common anti-patterns: committees that are rubber stamps, missing the right members, or meeting without clear actions.

topics.title: Policy Lifecycle Management
objectives: Implement a complete policy lifecycle: creation, review, approval, distribution, acknowledgment, and retirement
Establish policy review cycles and version control processes
Manage policy exceptions with a formal exception process
topics.promptHints: Policies are only useful if they're current and enforced. Walk through the complete lifecycle: drafting (who authors?), review (legal, HR, affected teams), approval (executive sign-off), distribution (how users access policies), acknowledgment (tracking that users have read and accepted), and retirement (sunsetting outdated policies). Cover annual review cycles and how to handle policy updates. Discuss the exception management process—when to grant exceptions, documentation requirements, time limits, and periodic re-evaluation.

topics.title: Security Awareness and Training Programs
objectives: Design a security awareness program that changes user behavior
Develop role-based security training for different audiences
Measure awareness program effectiveness through metrics and testing
topics.promptHints: Go beyond checkbox compliance training. Discuss how to design an awareness program that actually changes behavior—using adult learning principles, engagement techniques, and regular reinforcement. Cover program components: onboarding training, annual refresher, phishing simulations, security newsletters, lunch-and-learns. Show how to create role-based training (developer security training, executive cyber briefings, administrator privileged access training). Discuss measuring effectiveness: phishing simulation click rates over time, reported incidents, quiz scores, behavioral observations.

topics.title: Metrics and KPIs for Security Programs
objectives: Define meaningful security metrics and KPIs aligned with business objectives
Build security dashboards for operational and executive audiences
Use metrics to drive program improvement and investment decisions
topics.promptHints: What gets measured gets managed. Cover the challenge of measuring security—you can't easily measure attacks that didn't happen. Discuss categories of metrics: operational (MTTD, MTTR, patch compliance, vulnerability counts), program (policy compliance rates, training completion, audit finding closure), and risk (KRIs, risk treatment plan progress). Show how to build dashboards for different audiences. Discuss the danger of vanity metrics and how to choose metrics that drive action. Walk through creating a balanced security scorecard.

topics.title: Change Management and Governance in IT
objectives: Implement a change management process that balances control with agility
Classify changes and define appropriate approval workflows
Manage emergency changes and exceptions while maintaining control
topics.promptHints: Change management is a critical governance control. Walk through designing a change management process: change request, classification (standard/normal/emergency), risk assessment, approval (CAB or pre-approved), implementation, and post-implementation review. Discuss how to balance control with development velocity—pre-approved standard changes, automated testing gates, and fast-track processes. Cover handling emergency changes (retroactive approval, documentation requirements) and how to prevent change management from becoming a bottleneck. Use a real-world scenario of a company that had an outage due to an uncontrolled change.

topics.title: Security Program Strategy and Roadmapping
objectives: Develop a multi-year security strategy aligned with business objectives
Create a security roadmap with prioritized initiatives, milestones, and resource requirements
Present the security strategy to executive leadership and secure funding
topics.promptHints: This is CISO-level strategy work. Walk through developing a 3-5 year security strategy: assess current state (maturity assessment, gap analysis), define target state (aligned with business strategy and risk appetite), and build the roadmap to get there. Show how to prioritize initiatives using risk reduction, regulatory requirements, and business enablement criteria. Cover building the budget request and presenting to the board—using business language, showing ROI, and tying security investments to business outcomes. Use the scenario of a new CISO developing their first strategic plan.

topics.title: Organizational Design for Security Functions
objectives: Design the optimal organizational structure for the security function
Determine the reporting line for the CISO (CEO, CIO, CTO, General Counsel, Board)
Build a staffing model that addresses skill gaps with the right mix of hiring, outsourcing, and automation
topics.promptHints: Cover how to structure the security organization for maximum effectiveness. Discuss common models: centralized (single security team), federated (embedded security in business units), or hybrid. Analyze the pros/cons of different CISO reporting lines and their impact on independence and influence. Walk through workforce planning: identifying needed roles, skill gap analysis, build vs. buy decisions, managed services, and automation to multiply team capacity. Use the scenario of restructuring a security team after a major incident revealed organizational weaknesses.

topics.title: Board Reporting and Executive Communication
objectives: Prepare board-ready security reports that convey risk in business terms
Navigate board dynamics and tailor communication to different executive stakeholders
Respond to board questions about security incidents, investments, and benchmarking
topics.promptHints: Effective board communication is a critical CISO competency. Cover what boards want to know: Are we secure enough? Are we compliant? How do we compare to peers? Are we investing the right amount? Show how to translate technical security metrics into business risk language. Walk through preparing for a board meeting—anticipating questions, using benchmarking data, telling the risk narrative. Discuss handling crisis communication with the board during an active incident. Include SEC requirements for board-level cyber expertise.

topics.title: Security Culture and Business Integration
objectives: Embed security into business processes, product development, and digital transformation initiatives
Build security champion programs across the organization
Measure and evolve organizational security culture maturity
topics.promptHints: Move security from a gatekeeping function to an enabler of business. Discuss shift-left and security by design—embedding security into SDLC, product development, and business processes from the beginning. Cover building a security champions program: recruiting passionate employees from other departments, training them, giving them tools and recognition. Show how to measure security culture using surveys, behavioral metrics, and incident analysis. Use the example of a company transforming from a 'security says no' culture to one where security enables innovation.

topics.title: GRC Program Maturity and Continuous Improvement
objectives: Assess overall GRC program maturity using established maturity models
Design continuous improvement programs for governance, risk, and compliance
Benchmark GRC program effectiveness against industry peers and best practices
topics.promptHints: Take a holistic view of GRC program maturity. Walk through conducting a comprehensive GRC maturity assessment—evaluating governance structures, risk management processes, compliance operations, audit functions, and supporting technology. Show how to use results for prioritized improvement planning. Discuss benchmarking approaches: industry surveys, peer comparisons, maturity model scores. Cover implementing a continuous improvement cycle: assess, plan, implement, measure, adjust. Use the scenario of a company that wants to move from a reactive, compliance-driven GRC program to a proactive, risk-intelligent one.

domains.name: Incident Response & BCM
domains.description: Preparing for, detecting, responding to, and recovering from security incidents, business disruptions, and disasters through structured plans, exercises, and continuous improvement.

topics.title: Introduction to Incident Response
objectives: Define a security incident and distinguish it from a security event
Describe the NIST incident response lifecycle (Preparation, Detection & Analysis, Containment/Eradication/Recovery, Post-Incident Activity)
Identify the key roles in an incident response team (IRT)
topics.promptHints: Start with clear definitions and real examples. An event is a login attempt; an incident is a confirmed unauthorized access. Walk through the NIST 800-61 lifecycle phases with simple examples. Introduce IRT roles: incident commander, technical lead, communications, legal, HR. Discuss incident severity levels and how they determine response intensity. Use a phishing attack that leads to a compromised email account as the running scenario.

topics.title: Incident Detection and Classification
objectives: Identify common incident detection sources (SIEM, IDS, user reports, threat intelligence)
Apply an incident classification and severity framework
Perform initial triage and determine appropriate response levels
topics.promptHints: Cover how incidents are detected: automated tools (SIEM alerts, IDS/IPS, endpoint detection), human observation (user reports, helpdesk tickets), external notification (vendor advisories, law enforcement, threat intel). Walk through an incident classification scheme—categories (malware, unauthorized access, data breach, denial of service) and severity levels (1-4 with clear definitions). Show the triage process: validate, gather initial facts, classify, assign severity, and escalate. Use examples of real alert types and how to assess them.

topics.title: Business Continuity Planning Basics
objectives: Explain the purpose and components of a Business Continuity Plan (BCP)
Conduct a basic Business Impact Analysis (BIA) to identify critical processes
Define Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO)
topics.promptHints: Frame BCP as planning for the worst so business can continue. Walk through the BCP lifecycle: business impact analysis, risk assessment, strategy development, plan development, testing, and maintenance. Explain BIA in practical terms—identifying which business processes are most critical and what happens when they're disrupted for hours, days, or weeks. Define RTO and RPO with concrete examples: 'If our order processing system goes down, we can tolerate 4 hours (RTO) and can afford to lose 1 hour of data (RPO).' Use a manufacturing company dependent on IT systems as the example.

topics.title: Disaster Recovery Fundamentals
objectives: Distinguish between business continuity and disaster recovery
Identify common disaster recovery strategies (hot, warm, cold sites; backup approaches)
Create a basic disaster recovery plan for critical IT systems
topics.promptHints: Clarify the relationship: BCP is about business processes continuing, DR is about restoring IT systems and data. Cover DR strategies ranging from low-cost/slow-recovery (cold site, tape backups) to high-cost/fast-recovery (hot site, real-time replication). Discuss backup types (full, incremental, differential) and the 3-2-1 rule. Walk through creating a basic DR plan: system inventory, recovery priorities, procedures, contacts, and testing schedule. Use the scenario of a company planning DR for a cloud-based application with a database backend.

topics.title: Incident Communication and Notification
objectives: Develop internal and external incident communication procedures
Identify regulatory notification requirements for data breaches
Write effective incident notifications for different audiences
topics.promptHints: Communication can make or break incident response. Cover internal communication: who notifies whom, escalation paths, war room protocols. Then external: customer notification, regulatory notification requirements (GDPR 72-hour rule, state breach notification laws, sector-specific requirements), media handling, and law enforcement coordination. Show examples of good and bad breach notification letters. Discuss the balance between transparency and legal protection. Walk through a scenario where a company discovers a data breach affecting 50,000 customers.

topics.title: Building an Incident Response Plan
objectives: Develop a comprehensive incident response plan with playbooks for common incident types
Define escalation procedures, communication templates, and decision authorities
Integrate the IR plan with legal, HR, communications, and executive leadership
topics.promptHints: Move from concept to practical plan development. Walk through creating a complete IR plan: purpose and scope, team structure and roles, incident classification, playbooks for specific incident types (ransomware, data breach, insider threat, DDoS, supply chain compromise), escalation matrix, communication templates, and legal considerations. Show the difference between a playbook (decision-making guide) and a runbook (step-by-step procedures). Discuss integrating with other departments—when does legal get called? When does HR get involved? When does the CEO need to know?

topics.title: Tabletop Exercises and IR Testing
objectives: Design and facilitate tabletop exercises for incident response scenarios
Develop inject sequences that test decision-making and communication
Capture lessons learned and update plans based on exercise results
topics.promptHints: Tabletop exercises are the most cost-effective way to test IR plans. Walk through the complete process: choosing a scenario (realistic, relevant, and challenging), developing the exercise script with timed injects (new information revealed at intervals), facilitating the discussion, and producing an after-action report. Show a sample tabletop scenario—e.g., a ransomware attack that escalates from one server to critical systems over 4 hours. Include decision points: Do you pay the ransom? When do you notify customers? Do you call law enforcement? Discuss how to engage executives who are uncomfortable with technical scenarios.

topics.title: Business Continuity Strategy and Plan Development
objectives: Develop business continuity strategies for different disruption scenarios
Create detailed continuity plans for critical business processes
Implement plan maintenance, distribution, and accessibility protocols
topics.promptHints: Go deeper into BCP—from strategy to executable plans. Cover strategy options: alternate work locations, remote work capabilities, manual workarounds, alternate suppliers, cross-training. Walk through writing a continuity plan for a specific business process—the plan should be usable by someone unfamiliar with the process. Discuss plan format (concise, checklist-driven), accessibility during a disruption (don't store plans only on the systems that might be down), and maintenance (annual reviews, updates when processes change). Use a financial services firm planning continuity for customer-facing operations.

topics.title: Crisis Management and Leadership
objectives: Establish a crisis management team and command structure
Develop crisis communication strategies for media, customers, and regulators
Make high-stakes decisions under pressure with incomplete information
topics.promptHints: Crisis management is about leadership when things go very wrong. Distinguish crisis management (strategic, executive-level) from incident response (tactical, technical). Cover establishing the crisis management team: who's on it (CEO, CISO, General Counsel, Head of Communications, Head of Customer Service), how it activates, and decision authority. Discuss crisis communication—holding statements, press conferences, social media response, and customer communication. Walk through a major crisis scenario: a high-profile data breach that's hit the news, customers are calling, regulators are asking questions, and the stock price is dropping.

topics.title: Post-Incident Analysis and Improvement
objectives: Conduct effective post-incident reviews without blame
Identify root causes and contributing factors using structured analysis
Transform lessons learned into concrete improvements to policies, controls, and procedures
topics.promptHints: Post-incident analysis is where organizations actually learn and improve. Cover conducting blameless postmortems—focusing on systemic issues rather than individual blame. Walk through root cause analysis techniques: 5 Whys, fishbone diagrams, timeline analysis. Show how to document findings and transform them into actionable improvements—policy changes, control enhancements, training updates, technology investments. Discuss tracking improvement actions to completion. Use a real-world incident example and work through the postmortem process step by step.

topics.title: Advanced Incident Response: Ransomware and APTs
objectives: Develop response strategies for sophisticated threats including ransomware and APTs
Navigate the decision-making process for ransom payment scenarios
Coordinate with law enforcement, cyber insurers, and external IR firms
topics.promptHints: Cover the most challenging incident types. For ransomware: detection indicators, containment strategies (network segmentation, killing C2), the ransom payment decision (legal considerations, OFAC sanctions, insurance coverage, law enforcement guidance), and recovery from backups. For APTs: long-term compromise detection, living-off-the-land techniques, careful eradication to avoid alerting the attacker. Discuss working with external parties: cyber insurance claims process, engaging forensics firms, coordinating with FBI/CISA. Use a scenario where an organization discovers ransomware has encrypted 60% of its servers.

topics.title: Cyber Resilience and Organizational Resilience
objectives: Design a cyber resilience strategy that goes beyond traditional DR/BCP
Implement adaptive capacity and anti-fragile characteristics in systems and processes
Integrate cyber resilience with enterprise risk management and strategic planning
topics.promptHints: Move beyond recovery to resilience—the ability to absorb, adapt, and rapidly recover from disruptions. Discuss the shift from 'prevent all breaches' to 'assume breach and build resilience.' Cover resilience engineering principles: redundancy, diversity, modularity, fail-safe defaults, and adaptive capacity. Show how to assess organizational resilience maturity. Walk through designing systems that degrade gracefully rather than fail catastrophically. Discuss the relationship between cyber resilience and operational resilience (DORA, regulatory expectations). Use the example of a financial institution building a cyber resilience program.

topics.title: BC/DR Program Governance and Maturity
objectives: Build a mature BC/DR program with governance, metrics, and continuous improvement
Implement comprehensive testing programs including full-scale exercises
Navigate regulatory requirements for BC/DR across industries
topics.promptHints: Cover building and maturing a BC/DR program at the enterprise level. Discuss governance structures—BC/DR committee, program owner, plan owners, exercise coordinators. Walk through implementing a testing program: tabletop exercises (quarterly), functional exercises (semi-annually), and full-scale tests (annually). Cover ISO 22301 as the standard for BC management systems. Discuss regulatory requirements: FFIEC for financial services, CMS for healthcare, NERC for utilities. Show how to measure program maturity and present status to the board.

topics.title: Legal and Regulatory Aspects of Incident Response
objectives: Navigate legal requirements during incident response including preservation, privilege, and notification
Coordinate with legal counsel to protect attorney-client privilege during investigations
Manage regulatory reporting obligations across multiple jurisdictions
topics.promptHints: Cover the critical legal dimensions of incident response. Discuss evidence preservation and legal hold requirements—what must be preserved and how. Explain attorney-client privilege in the IR context: hiring forensics firms through outside counsel, privileged investigation reports, and the risk of privilege waiver. Walk through regulatory notification requirements across jurisdictions (GDPR, state laws, SEC, banking regulators) and managing conflicting timelines. Cover litigation risks and how IR documentation can be discoverable. Use the scenario of a multi-state data breach at a publicly traded company.

topics.title: Building an Incident Response Capability
objectives: Design and staff a Security Operations Center (SOC) or incident response capability
Implement SOAR platforms and IR automation to improve response times
Develop IR team skills through continuous training, certifications, and purple team exercises
topics.promptHints: Cover building the organizational capability for incident response. Discuss SOC models: in-house, outsourced (MSSP), or hybrid. Walk through staffing: skills needed, certification paths (GCIH, GCFA, GREM), hiring challenges, and retention strategies. Cover technology: SIEM, SOAR, EDR, threat intelligence platforms, and forensic tools. Discuss IR automation—automating triage, enrichment, containment actions, and notification. Show how purple team exercises improve both detection and response capabilities. Use the example of a company deciding between building an internal SOC vs. using an MSSP.

domains.name: Third-Party Risk
domains.description: Identifying, assessing, managing, and monitoring risks associated with third-party vendors, suppliers, service providers, and the broader supply chain throughout the vendor lifecycle.

topics.title: Introduction to Third-Party Risk Management
objectives: Explain why third-party risk management (TPRM) is critical in modern business
Identify the types of risks introduced by third parties (security, operational, compliance, reputational)
Describe the vendor lifecycle: selection, onboarding, monitoring, offboarding
topics.promptHints: Start with why this matters—use real breach examples caused by third parties (Target via HVAC vendor, SolarWinds supply chain attack, Okta via support contractor). Explain that organizations are only as secure as their weakest vendor. Cover the types of third-party risks and the complete vendor lifecycle. Discuss the difference between vendors, suppliers, service providers, and partners. Use the scenario of a company that discovers their cloud provider had a breach affecting their data.

topics.title: Vendor Risk Assessment Fundamentals
objectives: Classify vendors by risk tier based on data access, criticality, and exposure
Conduct a basic vendor security assessment using questionnaires
Evaluate vendor security posture using SOC reports and certifications
topics.promptHints: Walk through how to assess vendor risk. Start with vendor tiering—criteria for determining if a vendor is critical, high, medium, or low risk (what data do they access? How critical are they to operations? Can they be easily replaced?). Then cover assessment methods: security questionnaires (SIG, CAIQ, custom), reviewing SOC 2 reports, checking certifications (ISO 27001, PCI-DSS). Discuss the challenge of vendor assessment at scale—hundreds of vendors, limited staff. Use the example of assessing a new SaaS HR system that will store employee PII.

topics.title: Vendor Security Requirements and Contracts
objectives: Define security requirements to include in vendor contracts
Explain key contractual provisions: data handling, breach notification, audit rights
Draft security addenda and data processing agreements
topics.promptHints: Cover the contractual foundation of vendor risk management. Walk through essential security contract provisions: data handling and classification requirements, encryption requirements, access controls, breach notification timelines (often more aggressive than regulatory—e.g., 24-48 hours), right to audit, insurance requirements, subcontractor restrictions, data return/destruction on termination, and indemnification clauses. Show examples of contract language for each provision. Discuss negotiating with vendors who resist security requirements. Use the example of negotiating a contract with a cloud payroll provider.

topics.title: Due Diligence in Vendor Selection
objectives: Conduct pre-contract due diligence on potential vendors
Evaluate vendor financial stability, reputation, and security maturity
Document and present vendor risk findings to decision-makers
topics.promptHints: Cover the due diligence process before signing with a vendor. Walk through evaluating a vendor: security posture assessment (questionnaire, SOC report, pen test results), financial stability (can they stay in business?), legal/compliance standing (any regulatory actions?), references from other customers, and proof of concept/technical evaluation. Show how to create a vendor risk assessment report that helps decision-makers understand the risks and make an informed choice. Use the scenario of evaluating three competing cloud storage vendors for handling sensitive customer data.

topics.title: Fourth-Party Risk and Supply Chain Awareness
objectives: Explain fourth-party risk and why it matters (your vendor's vendors)
Identify supply chain risk scenarios and their potential impact
Map critical supply chain dependencies for key vendor relationships
topics.promptHints: Expand the risk perspective beyond direct vendors to the entire supply chain. Use the SolarWinds example to illustrate how a compromised supplier can affect thousands of organizations. Explain fourth-party risk: if your cloud provider uses AWS, and AWS has an outage, that affects you. Walk through identifying and mapping supply chain dependencies. Discuss concentration risk—when many organizations rely on the same few providers. Cover software supply chain risks (open source dependencies, compromised packages). Use a scenario where a critical vendor's subcontractor suffers a breach.

topics.title: Building a TPRM Program
objectives: Design a Third-Party Risk Management program with governance, policies, and procedures
Implement risk-based vendor tiering and assessment workflows
Establish vendor inventory management and ongoing monitoring processes
topics.promptHints: Walk through building a TPRM program from the ground up. Cover program governance (who owns TPRM—procurement, security, risk?), policy development (TPRM policy, assessment procedures, exception processes), vendor inventory management (how to maintain a complete list of vendors with risk classifications), assessment workflows (who does what, when, and how), and ongoing monitoring procedures. Discuss tools and automation for scaling TPRM. Use the scenario of a company with 500 vendors that currently has no formal TPRM program.

topics.title: Advanced Vendor Assessment Techniques
objectives: Conduct on-site vendor assessments and security reviews
Use external risk intelligence platforms for continuous vendor monitoring
Evaluate vendor security programs against specific frameworks and requirements
topics.promptHints: Go beyond questionnaires to more sophisticated assessment methods. Cover on-site assessments: planning, checklist development, interview techniques, physical security walkthrough, and documentation. Discuss external risk intelligence platforms (BitSight, SecurityScorecard, RiskRecon) that provide outside-in views of vendor security posture. Show how to use these tools for continuous monitoring rather than point-in-time assessments. Walk through evaluating a vendor against specific framework requirements (e.g., can this vendor support our ISO 27001 requirements?). Use the example of conducting an on-site assessment of a critical data center provider.

topics.title: SLA Management and Performance Monitoring
objectives: Design security and availability SLAs for vendor contracts
Implement SLA monitoring and reporting mechanisms
Manage SLA breaches and escalation procedures
topics.promptHints: Cover the operational side of vendor management. Walk through designing meaningful SLAs: availability (99.9% vs. 99.99%), response times for security incidents, patch management timelines, data handling requirements, and reporting obligations. Show how to monitor SLA compliance—dashboards, regular reporting, and automated alerting. Discuss handling SLA breaches: escalation procedures, remediation plans, financial penalties, and when to consider contract termination. Use the example of managing SLAs with a cloud infrastructure provider that experiences recurring availability issues.

topics.title: Vendor Incident Response and Business Continuity
objectives: Develop incident response procedures for vendor-related security events
Create vendor-specific business continuity and exit strategies
Coordinate incident response across organizational boundaries
topics.promptHints: Cover what happens when things go wrong with a vendor. Walk through vendor incident response: how to handle notification from a vendor about a breach, coordinating investigation across organizational boundaries, determining impact on your data and customers, and communication. Then cover exit strategies: planning for vendor failure or termination, data portability requirements, transition timelines, and avoiding vendor lock-in. Use the scenario of a critical SaaS vendor notifying you that they've experienced a data breach affecting your customer data.
