topics.title: Regulatory Requirements for Third-Party Risk
objectives: Navigate regulatory expectations for vendor management (OCC, FFIEC, GDPR)
Implement data processing agreements and processor management per GDPR requirements
Prepare for regulatory examinations of the vendor management program
topics.promptHints: Cover the regulatory landscape for TPRM. Walk through key regulatory guidance: OCC Bulletin 2013-29 (bank vendor management), FFIEC guidance, GDPR processor requirements (Article 28), and sector-specific requirements. Show how to implement GDPR data processing agreements and manage sub-processor chains. Discuss preparing for regulatory examination of the TPRM program—what examiners look for, common findings, and how to demonstrate a mature program. Use the scenario of a bank preparing for an OCC examination of its vendor management practices.

topics.title: Enterprise-Scale TPRM Program Management
objectives: Scale TPRM operations for organizations with thousands of vendor relationships
Implement automation and tooling to improve TPRM efficiency and coverage
Design TPRM metrics and reporting for executive and board audiences
topics.promptHints: Address the challenge of TPRM at enterprise scale—organizations with 5,000+ vendor relationships. Discuss automation strategies: automated questionnaire distribution and follow-up, API-based evidence collection, continuous monitoring tools, and risk scoring algorithms. Cover TPRM platforms (OneTrust, Prevalent, ProcessUnity, ServiceNow VRM) and how to evaluate and implement them. Show how to build a TPRM dashboard with metrics: assessment completion rates, average risk scores, overdue assessments, critical vendor issues. Use the scenario of a large financial institution modernizing its TPRM program.

topics.title: Supply Chain Security and Software Supply Chain Risk
objectives: Implement a comprehensive supply chain security program covering physical and digital supply chains
Manage software supply chain risks including open source, SBOMs, and build pipeline security
Apply frameworks like NIST C-SCRM and SLSA for supply chain risk management
topics.promptHints: Cover the increasingly critical area of supply chain security. Discuss physical supply chain risks (counterfeit components, tampering, geographic concentration) and digital supply chain risks (compromised software updates, malicious packages, vulnerable dependencies). Walk through implementing SBOMs—what they are, how to generate and consume them, and using them for vulnerability management. Cover NIST C-SCRM practices, SLSA levels for build integrity, and how to assess software supply chain risks. Use real incidents: SolarWinds, Log4j, Codecov, as case studies.

topics.title: Strategic Vendor Relationship Management
objectives: Develop strategic partnerships with critical vendors that include security collaboration
Implement vendor risk-sharing and joint security improvement programs
Navigate complex vendor ecosystems and platform dependencies
topics.promptHints: Move beyond adversarial vendor management to strategic partnership. Discuss how to work collaboratively with critical vendors on security—joint threat briefings, coordinated incident response exercises, shared security roadmaps. Cover risk-sharing models: how to structure partnerships where both parties have skin in the game. Address managing platform dependencies (AWS, Azure, Salesforce) where the vendor has significant leverage. Walk through designing a vendor governance model for a critical strategic relationship. Use the example of a company managing its relationship with its primary cloud provider.

topics.title: Third-Party Risk in M&A and Corporate Transactions
objectives: Assess third-party risk as part of M&A due diligence
Integrate vendor portfolios and TPRM programs during mergers and acquisitions
Manage vendor-related risks during divestitures and carve-outs
topics.promptHints: Cover the TPRM implications of corporate transactions. During M&A due diligence: assess the target's vendor portfolio, identify critical vendor dependencies, evaluate vendor contract terms (change of control clauses, assignment provisions), and inherited vendor risks. Post-acquisition: integrate vendor inventories, harmonize TPRM processes, and reassess vendor risk in the new context. For divestitures: untangle shared vendor relationships, negotiate transition services agreements, and establish new vendor contracts. Use the scenario of a company acquiring a smaller firm with 200 vendors and no formal TPRM program.

topics.title: Emerging Trends in Third-Party Risk
objectives: Evaluate the impact of AI and emerging technologies on third-party risk profiles
Implement zero-trust principles in vendor access and connectivity
Navigate evolving regulatory expectations for third-party oversight
topics.promptHints: Look at the future of TPRM. Cover AI-related vendor risks: vendors using AI to process your data (where does it go? is it used for training?), AI-powered risk assessment tools, and the need for AI-specific vendor requirements. Discuss zero-trust approaches to vendor access: just-in-time access, microsegmentation, API security, and continuous verification. Address API risks as more integrations move to API-based connectivity. Cover evolving regulations: EU DORA requirements for ICT third-party providers, SEC expectations, and the trend toward mandatory TPRM programs. Use the scenario of evaluating an AI vendor that will process sensitive customer data.

domains.name: Privacy
domains.description: Building and operating a privacy program that protects personal data, respects individual rights, and embeds privacy into organizational processes and technology through governance, engineering, and operational practices.

topics.title: Introduction to Data Privacy
objectives: Define personal data, PII, and sensitive personal data with examples from major privacy frameworks
Distinguish between data privacy and data security and explain how they complement each other
Identify the key stakeholders in an organization's privacy ecosystem (DPO, legal, engineering, business)
topics.promptHints: Start with the fundamental question: what is privacy and why does it matter? Define personal data broadly (GDPR's expansive definition) vs. PII (US-centric, narrower). Give concrete examples of each category—obvious PII (SSN, name) vs. less obvious personal data (IP addresses, cookie IDs, device fingerprints). Clearly distinguish privacy from security: security protects data from unauthorized access, privacy governs how data is collected, used, shared, and retained even by authorized parties. Use the analogy of a bank vault (security) vs. banking regulations (privacy). Discuss the privacy ecosystem within an organization and who owns what.

topics.title: Privacy Principles and Fair Information Practices
objectives: Explain the Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPPs) and their influence on modern privacy law
Describe the OECD Privacy Guidelines and their eight core principles
Apply Ann Cavoukian's seven Privacy by Design principles to real-world scenarios
topics.promptHints: Trace the history of privacy principles from the 1973 HEW report (FIPPs) through the 1980 OECD Guidelines to modern Privacy by Design. Cover FIPPs: notice/awareness, choice/consent, access/participation, integrity/security, enforcement/redress. Then the OECD's eight principles: collection limitation, data quality, purpose specification, use limitation, security safeguards, openness, individual participation, accountability. Then Cavoukian's seven PbD principles. Show how these foundational principles directly influenced GDPR's Article 5 principles. Use practical examples—how does 'data minimization' apply when building a customer registration form?

topics.title: Data Classification and Data Mapping
objectives: Build a data classification scheme that categorizes data by sensitivity and privacy impact
Conduct a data mapping exercise to identify what personal data is collected, where it flows, and who processes it
Create a Record of Processing Activities (RoPA) as required by GDPR Article 30
topics.promptHints: Cover the practical foundations of any privacy program. Start with data classification: why you need it, common tiers (public, internal, confidential, restricted), and how privacy adds a dimension (personal data categories, special categories under GDPR). Then move to data mapping: techniques for discovering what personal data exists across the organization (interviews, automated scanning, questionnaires to business units). Walk through creating a data flow diagram showing collection points, storage locations, processing purposes, sharing with third parties, and cross-border transfers. Then show how this feeds into a GDPR Article 30 RoPA. Use the example of mapping data flows for an e-commerce company.

topics.title: Global Privacy Regulatory Landscape
objectives: Compare the key provisions and scope of major global privacy laws (GDPR, CCPA/CPRA, LGPD, POPIA, PIPL)
Identify which privacy regulations apply based on an organization's data processing activities and geographic reach
Explain the trend toward comprehensive privacy legislation and its implications for global organizations
topics.promptHints: Provide a practitioner's survey of the global privacy landscape. Cover GDPR as the gold standard (extraterritorial reach, broad definition of personal data, heavy penalties). Then CCPA/CPRA in the US (consumer rights, opt-out model vs. GDPR's opt-in). Brazil's LGPD (GDPR-inspired but with unique provisions). South Africa's POPIA. China's PIPL (data localization, cross-border transfer restrictions). Touch on emerging laws in India, Japan (APPI), and the US state-level patchwork. Focus on practical differences: what triggers applicability, key rights granted, penalty structures, and cross-border transfer mechanisms. Use a scenario of a SaaS company with customers on five continents figuring out which laws apply.

topics.title: Individual Rights and Consent Models
objectives: List and explain the core data subject rights established across major privacy frameworks
Distinguish between consent models: opt-in, opt-out, legitimate interest, and other lawful bases
Evaluate when consent is the appropriate lawful basis vs. alternatives like legitimate interest or contractual necessity
topics.promptHints: Cover the individual rights that privacy laws grant to data subjects. Walk through GDPR rights: access (Article 15), rectification (Article 16), erasure/right to be forgotten (Article 17), restriction (Article 18), portability (Article 20), objection (Article 21), and automated decision-making (Article 22). Compare with CCPA rights: know, delete, opt-out of sale/sharing, non-discrimination. Then dive into consent models: GDPR's high bar for valid consent (freely given, specific, informed, unambiguous, affirmative action) vs. CCPA's opt-out model. Discuss when consent is NOT the best lawful basis—legitimate interest balancing test, contractual necessity, legal obligation. Use the scenario of a marketing team wanting to send emails to existing customers vs. new prospects.

topics.title: Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs and DPIAs)
objectives: Determine when a Privacy Impact Assessment or Data Protection Impact Assessment is required
Conduct a DPIA following a structured methodology including risk identification and mitigation
Integrate privacy assessments into the project lifecycle and change management processes
topics.promptHints: Cover the practical mechanics of conducting privacy assessments. Start with when DPIAs are required under GDPR Article 35 (systematic profiling, large-scale special category processing, systematic public monitoring) and the threshold/screening assessment to decide. Walk through a DPIA methodology step by step: describe the processing, assess necessity and proportionality, identify risks to individuals (not the organization), evaluate risk likelihood and severity, identify mitigation measures, document residual risk, and determine if prior consultation with the supervisory authority is needed. Show how to embed PIAs into the SDLC so they happen before development starts, not after. Provide a practical DPIA template. Use the scenario of assessing a new employee monitoring system.

topics.title: Data Subject Access Requests (DSARs)
objectives: Design an end-to-end DSAR fulfillment workflow from intake to response
Implement identity verification procedures that balance security with accessibility
Manage complex DSAR scenarios including exemptions, third-party data, and high-volume requests
topics.promptHints: Cover the operational challenge of handling DSARs at scale. Walk through the DSAR lifecycle: intake channels (web form, email, phone), identity verification (balancing security with friction—you can't demand a passport copy for a newsletter unsubscribe), searching across systems for the individual's data, reviewing and redacting third-party information, applying exemptions (legal privilege, trade secrets, others' rights), formatting the response, and delivering within the regulatory timeline (GDPR: 30 days, CCPA: 45 days). Discuss automation strategies: DSAR management platforms, pre-built data discovery queries, and self-service portals. Address edge cases: employee DSARs, requests from children's parents, vexatious requests. Use the scenario of a company receiving 50 DSARs per month and needing to build a scalable process.

topics.title: Consent Management and Preference Centers
objectives: Design a consent management architecture that captures, stores, and honors consent across systems
Implement cookie consent mechanisms compliant with GDPR, ePrivacy, and CCPA requirements
Build a user-facing preference center that gives individuals meaningful control over their data
topics.promptHints: Cover the technical and operational aspects of consent management. Start with consent architecture: how to capture consent with full context (what, when, who, which version of the notice), store consent records as audit evidence, and propagate consent decisions to downstream systems. Discuss cookie consent specifically: the ePrivacy Directive's requirements, GDPR's interpretation, the IAB Transparency and Consent Framework (TCF), and how CCPA's 'Do Not Sell' differs. Walk through implementing a Consent Management Platform (OneTrust, Cookiebot, custom) and the technical integration challenges. Then cover preference centers: letting users manage communication preferences, data sharing settings, and marketing opt-ins in one place. Use the scenario of a media company with a website, mobile app, and email newsletters needing unified consent management.

topics.title: Privacy by Design and Default
objectives: Embed privacy requirements into the software development lifecycle (SDLC) from design through deployment
Apply data minimization, pseudonymization, and anonymization techniques to reduce privacy risk
Implement privacy-protective default settings and architecture patterns
topics.promptHints: Cover the engineering side of privacy. Start with GDPR Article 25's legal requirement for data protection by design and by default. Walk through embedding privacy into the SDLC: privacy requirements gathering, threat modeling for privacy (LINDDUN methodology), design patterns (minimize, separate, abstract, hide, inform, control, enforce, demonstrate), privacy-focused code reviews, and privacy testing. Deep-dive on data minimization techniques: collect only what's needed, pseudonymize where possible (tokenization, hashing with salt), anonymize when feasible (k-anonymity, l-diversity, t-closeness). Discuss the tension between anonymization and data utility. Cover privacy-protective defaults: opt-out by default, minimal data collection in forms, automatic data retention limits. Use the scenario of a development team building a health and fitness app.

topics.title: Cross-Border Data Transfers
objectives: Navigate the legal mechanisms for transferring personal data across international borders
Implement Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) and conduct Transfer Impact Assessments
Address data localization requirements and design architectures that respect jurisdictional boundaries
topics.promptHints: Cover the complex area of international data transfers. Start with GDPR Chapter V: the general prohibition on transfers to countries without adequate protection, and the mechanisms to overcome it. Walk through adequacy decisions (which countries have them, the EU-US Data Privacy Framework and its history through Safe Harbor and Privacy Shield). Cover SCCs: the 2021 modernized clauses, the four modules (controller-to-controller, controller-to-processor, etc.), and the requirement for Transfer Impact Assessments (TIAs) post-Schrems II. Discuss BCRs for intra-group transfers. Address data localization laws that require data to stay in-country (Russia, China, certain sectors). Cover practical architecture patterns: regional data residency, processing in the origin region, and using local cloud regions. Use the scenario of a European company evaluating US-based cloud services after Schrems II.

topics.title: Building and Maturing a Privacy Program
objectives: Design a comprehensive privacy program with governance structure, policies, and operational procedures
Define the DPO role and build a privacy team that partners effectively with legal, IT, and business units
Assess privacy program maturity using established models and create a roadmap for improvement
topics.promptHints: Cover building a privacy program from the ground up and maturing it over time. Start with governance: privacy program charter, reporting structure (where does the DPO sit—legal, compliance, CISO?), privacy committee, and executive sponsorship. Walk through the DPO role: qualifications, independence requirements under GDPR Article 37-39, tasks and responsibilities, and how to avoid conflicts of interest. Cover the core program elements: privacy policies (internal and external), privacy notices, training and awareness, vendor privacy management, incident response for privacy breaches, and privacy by design integration. Then discuss maturity models: AICPA Privacy Maturity Model, IAPP's privacy program framework, and creating a multi-year roadmap with measurable milestones. Use the scenario of a mid-size company appointing its first DPO and building a privacy program from scratch.

topics.title: Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs)
objectives: Evaluate privacy-enhancing technologies and their applicability to different data processing scenarios
Compare differential privacy, homomorphic encryption, secure multi-party computation, and federated learning
Design data architectures that leverage PETs to enable data utility while preserving individual privacy
topics.promptHints: Cover the cutting-edge technical side of privacy. Start with why PETs matter: enabling data-driven decisions without compromising individual privacy. Walk through each major PET category with practical examples. Differential privacy: adding calibrated noise to query results (how Apple and Google use it for telemetry). Homomorphic encryption: computing on encrypted data without decrypting (limitations and current practical applications). Secure multi-party computation: multiple parties computing joint results without revealing individual inputs (use in financial benchmarking). Federated learning: training ML models without centralizing data (healthcare applications). Synthetic data: generating statistically representative datasets that contain no real personal data. Zero-knowledge proofs: proving a statement without revealing the underlying data (age verification without revealing birthdate). For each, discuss maturity level, performance trade-offs, and real-world adoption. Use the scenario of a healthcare consortium wanting to train an AI model across hospital datasets without sharing patient records.

topics.title: Data Breach Notification and Privacy Incident Response
objectives: Compare breach notification requirements across major privacy regulations and determine notification obligations
Design a privacy-specific incident response plan that covers detection, assessment, containment, and notification
Conduct breach severity assessments to determine individual harm and regulatory notification thresholds
topics.promptHints: Cover the privacy-specific aspects of breach response (distinct from general incident response which is in the IR domain). Start with what constitutes a personal data breach under GDPR (confidentiality, integrity, and availability breaches) vs. breach definitions under CCPA, HIPAA, and state breach notification laws. Walk through notification requirements: GDPR's 72-hour window to supervisory authority, individual notification when 'high risk,' CCPA's 'expedient' requirement, and the varying US state notification timelines. Cover the breach assessment methodology: determining the nature of the breach, categories and volume of data, likely consequences, and measures taken. Discuss the breach severity assessment to determine if notification thresholds are met. Cover the notification content requirements and communication strategies. Address the coordination between privacy, security, legal, and communications teams. Use the scenario of discovering that a database containing customer records was exposed to the internet for two weeks.

topics.title: Privacy in Emerging Technologies
objectives: Assess privacy risks specific to AI/ML systems including training data, model outputs, and automated decision-making
Evaluate privacy implications of IoT, biometric data collection, and location tracking technologies
Apply privacy frameworks to emerging technology scenarios including children's data and the EU AI Act
topics.promptHints: Cover privacy challenges posed by new and emerging technologies. Start with AI/ML privacy: training data consent issues, model memorization and data extraction attacks, automated decision-making rights under GDPR Article 22, explainability requirements, and the EU AI Act's privacy-relevant provisions (high-risk AI systems, transparency obligations). Cover biometric data: fingerprints, facial recognition, voice prints—their special category status under GDPR, Illinois BIPA, and the growing wave of biometric privacy laws. Address IoT privacy: smart home devices, wearables, connected vehicles—the challenge of providing notice and obtaining consent from ambient data collection. Discuss children's privacy: COPPA requirements, GDPR's provisions for children's consent (Article 8), the UK Age Appropriate Design Code, and California's Age-Appropriate Design Code Act. Use the scenario of a company deploying facial recognition for building access while also rolling out an AI chatbot for customer service.

topics.title: Privacy Program Metrics and Continuous Improvement
objectives: Design a privacy metrics framework that demonstrates program effectiveness to executives and regulators
Conduct internal privacy audits and assessments to identify gaps and measure compliance
Build a continuous improvement cycle that adapts the privacy program to regulatory changes and organizational growth
topics.promptHints: Cover how to measure, report on, and continuously improve a privacy program. Start with privacy metrics and KPIs: operational metrics (DSAR response times, DSAR volume, training completion rates, DPIA completion rates, consent rates), risk metrics (open privacy risks, incidents, vendor privacy compliance), and compliance metrics (policy coverage, RoPA completeness, regulatory findings). Show how to build a privacy dashboard for executive reporting and board-level communication. Cover privacy auditing: internal audit methodology, using ISO 27701 as an audit framework, common audit findings, and remediation tracking. Discuss regulatory readiness assessments: preparing for supervisory authority inquiries, maintaining evidence of compliance (accountability principle), and conducting mock regulatory inspections. Address continuous improvement: staying current with regulatory changes, updating the privacy program based on audit findings, benchmarking against industry peers, and adapting to organizational changes (new products, M&A, geographic expansion). Use the scenario of a privacy team presenting its annual program report to the board of directors.
